Without it getting graded, i just think it might make some stuff later easierWhen you have a finite symbol set, and an infinite domain, periodic mapping is almost inevitable. Let's say we have a representation of with weights Then we get a value here (because this is just binary)Can I use the exponent one up to reperesent the negative numbers? The outermost ring of the number wheel? Well the issue is what happens to zero. When you do that, two numbers end up mapping to zero so the function isn't bijective What is an appropriate mapping which can enable us to have values zeros through 63 OOH A MAPPING THAT HE'S SUGGESTING IS THAT WE HAVE SOME REPRESENTED NUMBER MINUS 32. This mapping is bijective from ! This is called a biased representation. Instead of (unsigned 6 bits), we have . Definition 2.2.1 (Biased Notation). The mapping to enable the representation of negative and positive integers through a bijective number The original (0-32) become negative, 32 becomes zero, 33-63 become positive numbers!! This is not a weighted code. A weighted code has to be a dot product, and here it isn't. To be a weighted code it has to be a dot product between . Now we'll look for a different mapping which is a weighted codeDefinition 2.2.2 (2s Compliment). 2s compliment is a weighted code and a bijective mapping to produce negative and positive integers. 2's compliment changes the weight of the MSB (most significant bit No matter the width of the bit-vector now, all 1's will always be Does there exist a bijective mapping which has the same number of negative and positive numbers? No, any mapping has to be even since we're in base two. Because we we have to represent zero, the amount of the set left to the natural numbers in the domain is odd and can't be split in half. I think this implies that in number systems with uneven bases, we should be able to represent an even bijective map. How do you go about performing linear combinations? This is a weighted code! It's just combining vectors What about multiplying So I think I can produce a weighted operator to allow me to multiply the values efficiently! Well what about dividing? I don't think there's an easy way to simplify this linearly. Well what if I want to convert a number from ^4000e6Definition 2.2.2 (2s Compliment) to a base with a lower value? Well it's just mod One of the most beautiful properly of 2s compliment is that if I want to increase the number of bits to represent a negative number, I can just keep adding 1s to the left! If Its a positive number I can keep putting 0's to the left. Basically just take the most significant bit to the spot that you want itWhen working with modulus, we define the remainder as having to be positive while also being less than the absolute value of the divisor. These rules are almost arbitrary, but they maintain that this is an appropriate mapping.

school/cs/cs-429/notes/3.1-boolean-algeb.description: We talked more about different operations we can do over finite representations of binary strings, and the associated interpretations of them. When we truncate, it's a modulus operation! For a number I an knock out the th higher bases in base then I performExample of expansion in signed numberBut how do we truncate on signed numbers? The goal is that we can relate it to something nice in a mathematical world. If I have my number wheel and I want to truncate it to a value , just toss out the digits that you want to get rid of, reconstruct your number wheel, and reinterpret. We don't care where we came from when we do this. It means the sign can change. Well why does even do this? It wasn't really intentional, this is just how they do it After chopping, what ever the most significant bit is of the remaining bit determines your sign. Either this is when you use 2.2 Number wheels > ^4000e6Definition 2.2.2 (2s Compliment) , or with 2.2 Number wheels > ^248dfbDefinition 2.2.1 (Biased Notation) The different operations you're looking at are either U2Sc or S2Uc. You can also have S2Sx (signed expansion), S2St (signed truncation) Similarly you can have U2Ux and U2Ut There is an overlap in the signed and unsigned space when the MSD (most significant digit) is 0. You're just interpreting it much bigger Boolean algebra is defined as the field of numbers composed ofWe know that any function can be expressed as a combination of NANDs and NORsI thought it was AND and XOR? Or for example is there an algorithm which runs faster in base 3 than base 2 I know that we get teh speedup in quantum computing, I'd assume tha answer is no becasue otherwise there would be a similar rush to other radix systems This is taking the entire bit vectors with another to make logical changes. Does boolean algebra form a ring? I think so you never get a place out of it, and it's destructive. You can also define different types of shifts. Logical shifts say not to worry about anything with the sign. >> or << just drop zeroes in Arithmetic shift to the right means you need to pad the sign coming in so that the number's semblance is where we have this.C does not tell us what to do when an arithmetic shift goes to the right. Right shift is always arithmetic. Drop in the signed bits from the side Most people in the world assume that if you do a right shift, by default it's assumed to be an arithmetic shift.

Damn about. 10-15% of submissions get flagged that's actually an insane ratio The rules coming from the university is that if any cheating is flagged by the tool, it goes straight to the authorities above. Kind of on this point but at any point should I start formatting my git commits? I know they said it wasn't required but as assignments get more complex watching my commit updates might make things easier to review Also do I need to remind him that I'm the class notetaker here or is it cool There are 3 types of char. There are char signed char, unsighed char. These are collectively the character types. In the int worlds, we consider signed ints and regular ints, they're the same type. This isn't so with the characters where they're al different types. What ranges will char use? You change the setting in the <limits.h>. 1CHAR_MIN = -128 -> char is signed2CHAR_MIN = 0 -> char is unsignedChar's will always be the same size as 1 byte. There is no concept of endianness with chars.
ASCII is just a codebook to map existing representations to values. It's an encoding/an interpretation. Because char is 1 byte long, we would think we'd have 256 representations. Sucks to suck, it's a 7 bit codeASCII is a 7 bit codeThe set of printable characters had in addition had some on printable character. There were also non-printable characters though! Things like shift, caps-lock, arrows, escape, etc. Those are control characters (0x00-0x1F,0x7F) The rest are printable characters (`0x20-0x7E) This range is the code-space! Each pattern is a code point. NUL has an ASCII code (this is the all zeroes charecter \0), but note that it's not NULL! That is a value In the ASCII codebook, they do expect to have some of the fields memorized The first 32 are non-printable characters Printables start from hex 20 Contiguous characters go from 0x30-0x39 Then capital letters is 0x41-0x5A. The difference between upper and lower case is 0x20 How do I go from the character 3 to the value 3? Well you can just subtract off the character 3 from the character zero! Then your bitwise representation is the same. You would need to cast though so that the interpretation is correct In C, you have a function atoi() which is a built in ASCII to integer function in <stdllib.h>. Before getting to atoi(), make sure you sanitize inputs first. It will blindly cast into integer representation assuming base 10 We now have a variable length representation for our codespace! ASCII has a fixed length, but now we're allowing for dynamic sizing. The need for a larger code literally exploded. This is a variable length character encoding. We need to always stay backward compatible, so ASCII must still remain. We can use 1,2,3, or 4 bytes When using 1 byte, it's the old ASCII code. Depending on what your needs are, it will dynamically resize. Exercise 4.1.1 (AT HOME: Do the unicode worksheet). Where is the worksheet? The first byte will indicate the number of bytes used in UTF-8. The continuation byte always begins with 10. There are as the total code space. school/cs/cs-429/notes/4.2-dynamic-memor.title: 4.2 Dynamic Memory Management Concepts
school/cs/cs-429/notes/4.2-dynamic-memor.description:
We discussed the basics of memory management and memory allocation. Dynamic memory management refers to the algorithms and structures for allocating and deallocating objects of variable size in memory at program execution time. The sequence data is given to the user, may not be the sequence it is returned to the computer. Lets say we fill in chairs row by row, but some peopled decide to leave early leaving holes! What that means is that we have to find a smart way to keep track of the data filling into the holes We also need an interface for the OS incase the user requests for more memory than you currently have permission for. Some examples of the above concepts in C are malloc()/free and new/delete in C++ The thing that manages this is called the ALLOCATOR. We're designing an explicit memory allocator that the user is responsible for using. In Python and Java, they use an implicit memory allocator (called a garbage collector). We'll learn more about this in OS These days when there is a guardrail which stops the stack from trying to collide with the heapThe allocator (malloc) has to keep track of which memory is marked as free, and which is marked as usedWhen I end up filling holes, I might fill that hole I'll probably leave behind a small sliver that no one can use. In that case, what do I even do? Because the odds of those small holes getting filled up are extraordinarily low There's no hard and fast answer to this. You could give the entire space to someone more than they asked so you know you get it all back used, but then they can overuse it. It's all statistics Whenever we request memory from malloc, if I request for example bytes, it actually saves , where one byte is for the metadata representing the width of the memory block. The chunks of memory managed from the OS are not necessarily contiguous to the first program chunkDoes the OS have it's own allocator which is taking requests from ours? Does it just have access to the entire block of RAM?In this case, the application is the mutator which then interacts with the allocator and engaging with Clang.Time efficiency: Maximizing throughput as the number of requests we take at a time in order. Can't service the memory requests out of sequence Tends to be the easier one to optimize for Space Efficiency: Maximize memory utilization, minimizing the wanted space If I request bytes as a payload, the allocator responds with a pointer to a block of bytes. The overhead of this operation was . Overhead can commonly come from things like alignment (the term for the question I asked earlier) and metadata You can just keep requesting more memory from the operating system and never free memory up. It's great with time, horrible with space. Before you ever code when working with the lab, absolutely draw out how you plan on implementing your design. Can we research existing malloc implementations to base ours off of Sure! But you have confined times so don't go overboard To keep track of our memory, we're going to use a linked list. The first element in the list will be the first free memory spot, pointing to the block itself and the next node. The metadata keeps track of the pointer to the next location as well. I'm not making a diagram of this myself because the class diagram is excellent
I can find this on page 13 of the lecture notes linked in the source

school/cs/cs-429/notes/4.3-dynamic-memor.title: 4.3 Dynamic Memory Management Details
school/cs/cs-429/notes/4.3-dynamic-memor.description:
Today we continued on from last class and discussed concepts we could use in the memory management assignment. Specifically he gave us tips on different data structures and considerations for the workContinuing on from [4.2 # Data Structures](4.2%20Dynamic%20Memory%20Management%20Concepts.md#Data Structures), nothing is stopping blocks from colliding other than a well behaved mutatorManaging this free space is what the goal of allocator design is. When managing these free lists, we need to keep into account Format: What do the blocks look like? Organization How do we keep track of every free block? There is no correct answer to this in our lab. We have to figure out what we want to design exactly with all the corner cases in advance. Otherwise debugging will be a nightmare Selection: How do I pick the right free block for a given request? How do I tell when I might want to give extra space for better sorting? Many blocks will be good candidates. I can maybe allow a user to pass in some tighter criteria on how memory is selected? Splitting: What to do with the remainder of the free block after allocating More on this in my first question in 4.2 Dynamic Memory Management Concepts4.2 Dynamic Memory Management Concepts Coalescing: How to handle a block returned to the list All of the contiguous free blocks will need to be merged together. See in the above diagram Are there any cases where I shouldn't merge contiguous blocks of free memory? Nope not for this lab, but when you do is up to you
The header should be a fixed length header. That way we know exactly where the size parameter sits. The size is 16 bytes back from the pointer in this case. Then what comes right before our pointer is the pointer to the next free block.The padding makes sure that the address that we have is a multiple of 16 bytes, always. We will not go through the reasons in here, but it's to do with keeping memory allocation efficiency (Is it related to memory buffers?). Keep things 16 bytes aligned It's worth it to waste some space for this sake Example 4.3.1 (Possible memory allocation with padding). Free blocks also need to have size and padding. If I'm implementing a doubly linked list, no one is using the memory inside the payload. This doubly linked list becomes only doubly linked when it's not in use. You'd need to keep track of the previous pointer though when repopulating Why do we put the header at the top though?The reason is because if our pointer was at the top, we wouldn't know where the size was! For example, in the left case size is located at . In the later case size is located at , but when we jump to the memory block we don't know the size!In an allocated block there is a block of memory that was apart of the free block linked list which is now useless. We can now put some well understood pattern into that section of memory which will warn us if someone had messed up with the data (someone might have overstepped). A common canary value in memory is often DEADBEEF
Silly question, wtf is deadbeef?? https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=0xDEADBEEF&redirect=no We are not allowed to use an explicit list in our memory management lab. An explicit list is one where all parts of memory are explicitly written out in a data structure, ordered and including occupied memory
We can't use an explicit list in the memory labOur recommendation is to use bucketed lists as our way of searching through all the free spaces. If you were a hotel booking a 50 person conference, you wouldn't look at the rooms for 5, 10, or 20 people. You'd look at the 100 people rooms all off the back. This is bucketing! His recommendation is to have the buckets tuned via a parameter so we can optimize for the assignment
This ends up acting interesting when we do coalescing mentioned before, because now free blocks need to be moved across buckets. Maybe each bucket has a priority queue contained in it? But then I still need to balance a tree each time
Class requirement is at least 4 bins Plus, what's the fastest way to modify our free list when memory is returned back to us? What's the best metric to sort our blocks of memory The end of the slide deck has some more thorough write-ups of the different kinds of implementations with their pros and consMAKE SURE THAT ANY HOLES LEFT ARE LARGER THAN METADATA None of the possible choices made is the correct choice to make. The below notes were made next class!A circular linked list might make things easier First Fit- When you pick the first possible place the memory can fit. Pro: Time fast Con: Biases your unusable small spaces near the beginning of the memory Next Fit- First time start from the head, find something for the first request, then when the next request comes in start from where you stopped. Implement via circular linked list Pro: Tiny holes are spread out across the memory Con: Not sure Best Fit- Pick the block over all the data which best sizes the requested memory Pro: Obvious heuristic, minimizes unused allocated memory Con: makes really small unusable memory chunks Causes internal fragmentation (fragmentation inside the space given internal to you) Worst Fit- Pick the worst fitting block and allocate it Pro: Makes larger usable chunks for blocks Con: Can be more difficult for splitting? Didn't catch this Causes external fragmentation (fragmentation in the blocks we can allocate) Do we split a free block after allocation or not split? Or maybe if the size is smaller than a certain threshold (For example if we're smaller than the size of the header) we don't allocate that area . Going from an allocated block to a free block, which means we have to update our datastructure. If the block being free is in the middle of two allocated block, there's no need for them to absorb each other. From last time, diagram of the problem:We're required to coalesce. Do we need to check every-time a block is freed whether it has to be merged, or to I merge everyone after times. For implementation I can make a parameter for the update, and then I can set it to 1 if I find out I want it to update each cycle. We can also use BOUNDARY TAGS! We can make coalescing faster if we give each block it's metadata at the header and the footer. Then the current block can check if the previous one needs to be freed by subtracting 16 bits from it's current pointer. We couldn't do that before because we wouldn't know where it started for the metadata without already having the metadata. I also like this idea Exercise 4.3.2 (AT HOME: Think about what happens to the boundary tags when the pointers update).

school/cs/cs-429/notes/6.1-pointers.html.title: 6.1 Pointers
school/cs/cs-429/notes/6.1-pointers.html.description:
Today we're learning seven facts about pointersTo declare the type of a pointer, you use the form T* x;, where T is the target type. When would you use a pointer to a pointer? Ex char** cpp
You might have a set of pointers to objects, that you then want to switch across. The pointers to the objects themselves don't move, but our outer pointer switches across them!
Obj*Obj*Obj*Obj**Object to hold the cases
At the machine level, the pointers themselves memory addresses don't contain any type information! It takes 64 bits to take me to any spot in my memory, so the width of the pointer itself has the same size. That then begs the question, where is the type stored?The value of a pointer is then the address.
The NULL pointer denotes a num pointer constant which can't be dereferenced. When a pointer is uninitialized it will hold the address of an arbitrary memory location. If I have an uninitialized pointer int *xp and I want to make it so that I can then initialize it with the location of int x, then I can use the dereference operator &! With int* xp =&x I then make the pointer directed toward where x is located.You can get the address in multiple ways.
One thing that doesn't make any sense is int **z = &(x&). The address of x is not an L value, it hasn't been stored anywhere so it has no address to dereference to. The type of a pointer tells us how the pointers should increment when we add to them! An int *p+1 will increment by 8 bytes, while if I casted to (char)*p+1 I'd move forward by 4 characters.Where is the type of a pointer then stored? Where are types stored at all in C?You can reference the name of an array as a pointer variable. The type of an array is just a pointer to the type it targets. *s = 'h's[0]='h'The width that you jump is equal to the type of your arrayCasting a pointer into a different type just changes the interpretation of the existing data. Nothing about the data itself changed.
Casting obeys order of operations, so it slides in the same section as multiplication. What is the result of (int*)ptr*5?
I think when even, it would go LTR like how ties are broken on standard PEMDAS This is less related to class, but what is the best way to, via bit manipulation, flip a bitstringYou can make pointers which target functions!
Can I use this with environment variables to change which
For a function pointer, you do int (*fp) (int,int*). This just yields the structure and type of the function. I think you can do something fun with structs and function pointers to rebuild Java objects! Now I can have to different objects with their own toStrings! With this, I can rebuild the object system (without polymorphism)

school/cs/cs-429/notes/6.2-data-alignmen.title: 6.2 Data Alignment
school/cs/cs-429/notes/6.2-data-alignmen.description:
This is the last topic coming up to Exam 1. We should be completely caught up on what to study for the exam. There will be more on this tomorrow since we ran over! Today we covered how objects are placed in memory and how that behaves.It is possible that we run across a problem where we request a section of memory, it gets broken in half! The microprocessor ends up having to request both chunks.Notice that char a in the diagram is still contiguous! But now I'm still across 2 bytesIn the above case if I were to split one datatype across bytes, I'd need to for one char access memory twice. Either I spend time cleaning up my memory so that this doesn't happen, or I increase the I/O bus bandwidth to make more We need to make sure that our objects are residing in well defined spotsBasic datatypes have at runtime known sizes in memory, but structs don't! AArch64 requires 4 byte alignment for instructionsFor any object had for a particular type, then those types have to be on boundaries of a certain size as a multiple of byte addresses. Something is aligned ifThe address must be a multiple of the size. A character can go anywhere, a short has to exist at only even registers, a character can go anywhere.Did we need to accommodate that on the MM assignment? Nope actual writing to memory is below our scope onto the OS. We just allocate An aggregate object of a derived data type T (an array, struct, etc) is aligned IFF Every sub-object is recursively aligned. Every sub-type must follow it's respective rules. Does this mean that the order that I define datatypes in a struct can change the amount of space? Like if I defined the short first, and then an int, would I reduce the space of the struct by changing the order? YEP! Switching around the types in a struct can reduce it's memory size. Declaring variables in an accommodating order will reduce their memory usage And there's also the array rule, every element of an object y of type "Array of T" is also aligned. Does that mean the SIZE of a struct/abstracted datatype, then is the alignment requirement a multiple of that? NO! That only applies for primitives. We align abstracted datatypes based on the primitive type containing it which requires the most memory For every object, there are two decisions which have to be made. What the address is, and what the size of the object in. Basic types only have to decide the address With complex types we have to also determine the size! Derived types demand this analysis on the padding. I think it could be really fun to try redoing my MM lab with object oriented programing using that trick from earlier뵢n To pass the array rule, the spot at the end of the struct has to be a possible spot that I can drop a new struct in consecutively.
If ther eare two possible ways to pad a given structure, how does C break the tie. In the above image, there are two possible valid alignments. How to we decide?
We have to pad the last value because of the array rule. The very last byte has to be a multiple of our most constrainedIs there a code demo we can see to better understand the rules for how this is setup?Exercise 6.2.1 (AT HOME: Work out how a union would behave, like if a union might have struct elements). I think to follow the array rule you'd need the LCM of each struct, so that the alignment is always promised to be a multiple of their most constrained element.

I think to follow the array rule you'd need the LCM of each struct, so that the alignment is always promised to be a multiple of their most constrained element. Definition 6.3.2 (Instruction Set Architecture (ISA)). The definition of the format and behavior of machine-level programs. It defines the machine state and how the instructions change the machine state The machine state is like carrying a backpack with you. If you're walking along a path and you see something that is going to change you, you pick it up and drop it in the backpackThe ISA has two interfaces. A higher privilege one which gets to talk to the OS, and a lower sad one that us lowly programmers interface with. Assembly is a symbolic representation of machine language in human form.

Sorry I was a bit spaced today studying other notes while taking these! Today we covered more on the joint between machine processing and programmer writting.An instruction is a bitstring interpreted as a verb over a noun. At a semantic level, the verb makes a map between machine states to machine states. An instruction needs to have Source operands Operation Code Destination Is this why our CI Lab assignment was structured the way that they were? Yes that is exactly it! Using what we learned in our CI lab i sthe key point. I can study off my implementation and its codebase We keep track of the flags after each operation so that we can keep track of every operation. There are also fixed program and stored program computers. They're designed for specific tasks, reprogramming it would be complicated or up to impossible. Think of a music box! They are designed to have a fixed program. Our devices contrast the fixed program computers! We can change the programs inside them. They can store and run the programs. Von Neumann was the one who came up with the concept of a processing unit. This was the Von Neumann Architecture. DUDE WAS A POWERHOUSE I FORGOT ABOUT HIS QIS THEORY STUFF ../../../Physics/QIS/Notes/2.11 Fault-Tolerant Computation > ^89e110../../../Physics/QIS/Notes/2.11 Fault-Tolerant Computation > ^89e110
../../../Physics/QIS/Notes/1.13 Interpretations of Quantum Mechanics and Entanglement > ^858417Definition 1.13.1 (Von Neuman Entropy) The issue with his architecture was that memory was not isolated. The commands could get modified as the program ran
Plus there was only one stream running along the input-output bus. Only one connection links the processor and memory. HOLY SHIT VON NEUMANN CAME UP WITH THE DENSITY MARTIX FORMALISM? John von Neumann (December 28, 1903 February 8, 1957) was a Hungarian and American mathematician, physicist, computer scientist and engineer. To repair the Von Neumann flaws, there was the Harvard Architecture. ARM's architecture designed what the hypothetical machine looked like, not what the chip was. That way a vendor could create information on both ends. There are two architectures for ARM. AArch64 vs AArch 32. We're breaking the type of levels that we are allowed to access in 4 different levels. EL0, EL1, EL2, and EL3. EL3 is the highest priority like the operating system. We work in the realm of EL0.
ARM uses a load-store architecture. All you can do is load something, act on the whole thing, then drop it back away. You cannot act directly on memory contents!It might take longer to get the data, Reduced Instruction Set Computer - RISC Ohh that's where RISC-V gets it's name! Complex Instruction Set Computer - CISC They give us 31 registers to mess around with. THIS IS WHY WE COULD ONLY USE 32 VARIABLES AT A TIME IN CI LAB! THAT'S FREAKING WHY!! Don't use X30 and X29, we talk about it later but it gets complicated. The zero register is the 32nd register! You can only read 0x0 from it. It's a garbage can basically? Kind of, but we can also just pull the zero bitstring from it which can be helpful! The program counter is always holding the address of the current instruction. I can review this more thoroughly when reading the docs of CI Lab The stack pointer points to the stack register. The stack pointer is within the mutation scope of the programmer, the program counter is not like this There is the process state, which is an abstraction of the information. There are 4 program flags at our exception level N: Negative condition flag (Last computation resulted in negative flag is 1) Zero condition flag (if resulted in zero this flag is 1) unsigned Carry flag is 1 V signed oVerflow condition We can observe these flags. Exception levels above ours can play with more flags than this. They govern how our program runs.

school/cs/cs-429/notes/7.1-operands-and-.title: 7.1 Operands and Data Processing
school/cs/cs-429/notes/7.1-operands-and-.description: Much of today was explaining design decisions from the CI Lab assignment. We learned more about the ARM architecture, and then about different operand types and inputs.There are 2^64 places we can put things, but in ARM, we define two different twists to keep to things Normal: Used for most reading and writing Pointer subsets which point to something else, DEVICES! Whatever I'm typing on this keyboard is interpreted as coming from a memory location. This way I can read off the input of a device through specific pointer How do I find out what pointers are to the devices?REMEMBER instructions must be word-aligned Data alignment rules are complicated For my ARM instructions, they are always little-endian. Endianness of regular memory is configurable at EL1 or higher. Always assume little-endian unless told otherwise.All memory mapped peripherals should also be little endian! To accommodate this, we get drivers.Program evolution should always map internally to valid states. The state of a computer is contained within the processes of memory and the processor itself. bits Notice how the data memory is in a separate spot from the instruction memory like the harvard architectureharvard architecture. Fetch the instruction from the location pointed to my the program counter Decode the instruction word (The lexer in CI Lab did this first step of pulling information in) Operation, operands, results The instructions are like verb noun1 noun2 Read off the operands from the registers Execute the operation determined off by this Access the memory Write the results back to the register The reason that 5 is after 4 is because what I dump back might be contingent on what I read off of the memory.After all this, you have to move to the next instruction! 6. Update PC with the value we need to assign to it (think of branching for when this might not be consecutive incrementing) What we learn across the stages persists as we step. The form of an instruction is IW = (Operation, Operands, result locations) What are possible operands? Variables I change, the registers/pointers, or even a straight up constant. You'd do that when you want to increment a pointer by a known amount. The results are placed in a register or groups of memory cells A specification used for the constants within the instruction itself. They are also like the hex notation of #0x to tell us how to interpret the number (For assembly). Some compilers now don't need the #, but it's less ambiguous to place it anyway.The interpretation is known and persistent across program states. These were used a lot in CI-lab!I am terribly caffeinated.The information that I want from is sitting in my registers. You call then using either an X or a W. W uses the lower 32 bits only while the upper 32 bits are cleared to zero XZR,WZR is the zero registers SP,WSP is the current stack pointer. The regular SP is 64bit and is not notated by X

We can implement a traditional while loop by checking the negative form of our condition and if true, jumping to the exit. Otherwise we fall through to a standard do-while! The guarded do has two checks. One in the beginning (the guard), and one in the decider of continuing the loop. There are 5 different physically in the machine instructions, and the instructions that's reading the reigster at any aparticular cycle is the instruction that's in decode At the same point in time, what's writing information is what's in writebackWe need to do some non-trivial rewiting so that the decoding register is holding the decoding informationFetch , update, execute, memory, WritebackEverything is on the same clock, and it all goes through the five satges.This is a simplified visual representation of the state of the pipeline as a function of time The local stage view comes from the vertical. The global configuration view is horizontal, and the trajectory of an instruction is along the main diagonal. The crystal ball holds unknown information at clock start. Those are called "pipeline bubbles". There's no instruction in that stage at that point in the cycle. There are three views of the pipeline to think aboutWe carry the destination register with us because we need to keep track of it later for the write back. The hardest section is fetch instructionsTo be able to pass our parameter on, we need to be ablet o fatch our next program counter will be. Need something in to take it out. In math we call this a predictor corrector method. We make a prediction, hopefully a good prediction, and then take corrective action in case we're wrong. Static branch prediction methods are the primitive ones that we think about, but irl they do dynamic branch prediction methods to figure out where to go next. F- For us, If you see a capital letter like F,D,MX,W it tells you which register it's coming from. If we predict correctly that the branch was taken, all is good. If the prediction was incorrect, we have to go back and do work from the sequential successor pc of that branch instruction. When we hit execute, you evaluate the condition over there and will know then if the condition is true or false When we have the condition, we just come back around and check against the condition to overwrite it. The situation of returning (with the opcode being a return) With the return we call it "minus one". The priority is taking the seq_succ_pc, then the next up is val_a, and finally just continue with your prediction as the last possible option. You HAVE to move just one cycle at a time, which is super duper important Order of Priority When doing Corrections If you're getting a correction being signaled from an earlier mispredicted contitional branch. The return If neither of those corrections apply, go with the predicted PC There are some signals which are getting carried through. school/cs/cs-429/notes/12.2-pipeline-haz.title: 12.2 Pipeline Hazards
school/cs/cs-429/notes/12.2-pipeline-haz.description:
Even if you insert instructions in between, the dependency shouldn't be absolved. Those instructions might not cause a problem, but if it does how do we resolve it?Being independent just means there isn't a direct dependency between two instructions. Hazards are our dependency problems. They are a boolean valued function of an ISA implementation , with a set of instructions with or . If the non-pipelined version results in a different answer between my implementation of pipeline, we know it caused a problem.The ideal distance between two instructions with dependency is three. The subsequent instruction will need the previous information at decode, but the initial instruction will put pen to paper at writeback. If we let them be 3 apart, then we're safe because our previous instruction wrote to memory in time. What components of the machine can cause hazards? The control would have it (read in F, written in F,X,M) We can't let program dependencies become hazards. How can we change PIPE so that we can remain faithful to SSE and still pipelining. Within my space of correct solution, take the one which gives us the best efficiency Solutions are described in terms of "policies" and "mechanisms" Policies - What we gotta do Mechanisms - How we're gonna do it To stall for data hazards, we put ghost instructions which cause no effect so that the useful information can propagate. This is what bubbling is!Noop is an actual assembly command which does nothing. In the bubble you drop in, you're mimicking what the noop does. The useful things about the ghosts is that they stop the entire flow of instruction. This is stallingLoad Use Hazard - You're trying to load something from your memory to registers, and the next instruction is trying to read it. Branch prediction right now is predicting that we took that path. We need to know in fetch where to branch, but know the condition in executer. We can't just leave those faulty instruction there, unlike bubbling we need to throw them out. This is squashingIn our existing FDXMW model, we understand data as coming in from the left, and going out on the right. But for bubbling and squashing, we need to be able to intervene at a different point without passing all the way through thte pipeline. How do we do that? See 12.3 The PIPE Implementation12.3 The PIPE Implementation The way we squash them, is just introducing bubbles at their output. Since in fetch we pocketed the other possible direction, we know what we can do instantly!
See 11.4 SEQ to PIPE- > Fetch Stage11.4 SEQ to PIPE- > Fetch Stage for more information on this! For a mispredicted branch, we already result in two squashes. With squashing, we lost Two cyclesWith a return statement we have to know where to go back to in X30 by the time we hit the execute. We would know by the time we hit decode. For this when we hit a return, we just insert one bubble at D. Decode is when we find out what our instruction is. We need help from pipeline control to squash whoever came into fetch

school/cs/cs-429/notes/12.3-the-pipe-imp.title: 12.3 The PIPE Implementation
school/cs/cs-429/notes/12.3-the-pipe-imp.description: I wrote out what was needed from last lecture in it's personal documentThe only change is that for Exam 3 we get three cheatsheetsIs there something better than stalling or bubbles, because we don't like the wastage. We're changing it from making us wait a cycle, and instead trying to find a way to integrate data from the whole cycle to each other. By the end of X, we do have our calculation done its just not written. Can we use that information straight from X? This gets us to FORWARDINGSneakily through a different set of wires, interconnecting bidirectional movement between FDXMW. That way we don't have any useless points. We're going to get perpetual feedback coming in. If the register coming in from fetch is the same as any registers already in the pipeline, then you use the information they give you. You get to see the future!How do we prioritize the values based on where we're coming from?When we're working with the registers themselves, we use two bits to determine if a FDXMW is bubbled or stalled or normal. Just like latchlatchHow do we handle errors that come up in clumpsThe pipeline control unit sits orthogonal to the entire unit. IT makes the determination on which of these registers which lie. We give our feedback to the pipeline control Each one of the states can get different commands, and they can march at different rates.With def use, we can get away with no penalty through forwarding. With conditional branching, we have some possible luck on being right which is why it makes sense to pull in a guess. With return we have no idea where to go, so whatever we do is just as good as "propping your feet up on a chair"When I tell something to stall, in the next cycle where it would have gone is a bubble which propagates diagonally.With the mispredicted branch we don't need to backtrack and stall, since we carried PC+4 with us!

school/cs/cs-429/notes/12.4-pipe-part-2..title: 12.4 PIPE Part 2
school/cs/cs-429/notes/12.4-pipe-part-2..description:
Topics from last time added to previous note We're discussing how to handle edge cases on the PIPE implementation and evaluating it's performanceWe can't have LDUR and B.cond in execute at the same time, so they can't be simultaneous. We can haveIf my b.cond turned out to be the wrong prediction, we take care of our return because we don't care who's out there. That is automaticaly taken care of us by generically taking the b.cond solution in 12.3 The PIPE Implementation12.3 The PIPE ImplementationCombination B is LDUR in X30, ret. We only have a problem with X30 in the return case since without X30 we can't return to anythingWell can't we not return to anything with X29 loaded into as well? You're a bad programmer if you do that. - teacher But aren't I a bad programmer if I do that with X30? changing X30 still allows the program to run at all. Changing X29 will damage the logic flow There are 3 internally generated exceptions, statuses which propagate down the stages. Stat==HLT a halt instruction generated in fetch. Program completed! You need everything else to finish before you're allowed to stop! because we're a pipeline machine, we can't stop until we're at the end of the line Stat == INS imem_err is asserted, or an instruction with an invalid opcode. Generated in F. Memory error takes pace in the memory step Writeback can't get that information, but when a problem is detected in a particular stage, people ahead have to run to completion because they also can have their own problems which take priority. Exceptions do propagate back down the line Stat == ADR dmem_err State updates take place in XMW. They occur early in the pipeline. If the problem occured in writeback, X and M are not allowed to make a state update. Remember we have to match what we expect from SSE. The effect of X and M are not allowed to be seen.Priority is to the earliest excepting instruction. If a problem occurred in W while we're in M, then the M stage might try to update the memory when we're not allowed to. The execute stage might try to update a register when we're just not allowed.If we get a mispredicted branch, then in the branch there is a error, we should squash the new errored instruction loaded into memoryLong sequence of on PIPE. What's the minimum about of cycles needed to get us out the door. Ideally with cycles we pump instructions. But because of bubbles and stalls, this isn't always 1:1. The number of cycles should be of the form where . is the amount of bubbles The cycles per instruction isDefinition 12.4.1 (Cycles Per Instruction (CPI)). There is an approximate penalty of 3 possible cases for penalty Load Penalty 1 cycle for every load-use hazard Misprediction Penalty : 2 cycles for every mispredicted branch Return Penalty Exercise (Are we overestimating or underestimating?). Underestimating. With a mispredicted branch which caused a conditional, we squashed an instruction with the error which is another wasted cycle right?

school/cs/cs-429/notes/13.1-data-storage.title: 13.1 Data Storage Technologies
school/cs/cs-429/notes/13.1-data-storage.description: We made the assumption that the memory stage in PIPE took the same amount of time as the other stages. We could say the memory stage was the same time period of our other stages. Our processors have sped up thousands of times more than our memory has! How do we keep our pipeline moving?Ideally, we'd have infinite memory, extremely fast, and zero cost. This is an illusion. This can't really happen IRL. We might not be able to do this, but we can make an illusion of it! We have to tradeoff mainly between speed, density, quantity, and cost. We'll study a lot more of these concepts in OS The information is stored in the orientation of the logic, as opposed to the raw amplitude. It's a [dipole]((3.5 Induced Dipole Dipole Interaction3.5 Induced Dipole Dipole Interaction) (2.6 Conductors vs Dielectrics2.6 Conductors vs Dielectrics! This is a robust, persistent, volatile, resilient system! Isn't our capacitor system also sensitive to noise it produces itself? Because we're going to get local inductor effects right?We also have capacitors all over the chip to dampen the different high amplitude&frequency noise.Non volatile memory (read only memory) is like if you blew a fuse to a house. Once the fuse is burnt, the signal is passed. Fused? 1. Unfused? Zero.

school/cs/cs-429/notes/13.3-structure-of.title: 13.3 Structure of Caches
school/cs/cs-429/notes/13.3-structure-of.description:
Today we talked about the physical structure of our caches, along with how our memory address is structured to work with both the cache and physical memory.Our caching habits are going to be reactive, but in real lief we also cache proactively "This process is asking for this guy a lot, we should save his neighbors just in case" Cache's only improve performance, with no impact on correctness. Fibbionacci Number CalculationFibbionacci Number Calculation We've worked with caching before on a higher level of abstraction, it was dynamic programming! We want the illusion of near infinite space and near instant access.
Our ideal memory was a array of bytes (m is the 3.2 Byte Ordering, Integer Arithmetic > ^dcbb67Definition 3.2.1 (Word Size)). What we'd ideally like to see, is pulling nearby neighbors at the same time! That way we can cache the adjacent element just in case.Can I exploit this? If I'm a program and I request memory right at the boundary of my access, the block is fetched. Is there a way for me to access what would have been otherwise restricted? Wait till after thanksgiving he'll answer this
We use this blocking to incorporate spacial proximity.
A memory byte address turns into a pair . The memory address of the block, and then the offset from the starting point of the block.Because we're incorporating this blocking, we can start to see spacial correlation coming into play. This is just numbering like floors in an apartment building For our processor's concern, the dotted lines are our memory
We get the capacity of and the latency of $. We transfer entire memory blocks between $ and M. This gives our capacity of M and latency of $. The cache is a pretty small size though, so what happens when the cache fills up? Who's the first to go? A block of memory is the same as a line of cache. Our caches dwarf the total addressable space, so we want to find a way to preserve our illusions. But how do we find out if something is in our cache? - We can have a hashmap to understand if something is there. We can't afford to run through the full cache We can use to detect of our memory is going to exist, but we'd need to have blocks at least to be able to check that. We need to find a way to identify the exact place where our block could exist in the cache.
We do run into a #pigeonhole* problem, so how do we identify a single pigeon from multiple pigeons in the same hole? With hash-maps we solved this with linked lists. We want a constant time algorithm to access our cache. The size of our hashmap, of our reduced cache domain, is called the "cache set" There's a possibility (as mentioned in my pigeonhole problem), that there are multiple cache lines for a cache set. We store them sequentially themThe number of lines per cache is given by the ratio of blocks to cache lines. That's what cache associativity is.Could I like, have another second layer of the hashmap to help me identify once I'm at the second level? That way we don't need to linearly traverse based on the overlapDefined with $(ABC). A is the associativity (rooms to a floor) B is the line size (Memory block size) Bedrooms per hotel room C is the capacity number of bedrooms The number of cache sets In our case then, as the number of cache sets, is the number of floors.
Shoutout #dimensionalAnalysis We could use any artificial mapping for our set selection.
With middle order bit indexing though, we maintain access for spacial adjacency.
Our tag tells us who the guy we're looking for in the room. If a room has 8000 people who can be in it, the tag tells us who's actually in the room. We can instantly zero in to the room, and then confirm with the tag to know that we got what we wanted. A tag we put outside the door of the hotel room

So we occupy the same memory but interpret it as two different structs with different field sizes? Yes this is right! What happens to our cache when the power comes on? Our cache is going to contain garbage in it! How do you know that the address in our cache is what the address is supposed to be?
That's our valid column! As part of the startup process when the computer turns on, we reset all the valid bits. If we can wipe the cache on a startup process, then why don't we just zero out the cache? Because the less bits that we modify, the less time we take If our block is present in the cache, we call this a cache hit. Otherwise, we missed. Ideally our ratio of misses to hits is as close to zero as possible We do this when our tags match Precondition We found the memory block in the Cache We use the block offset to index to the resident memory block, read the value, and return it to the processor What happens if the bits required span multiple blocks? "We're going into the fridge, not finding milk, going to the store and buying milk, and putting it into a fridge with space." Same Actions as before Then we update the valid and tag bits for the line Update the cache copy of the memory block. When do we update the source though? We can update it the moment the cache is updated We can update it the moment we evict the cache this just means the simplest implementation would be to always write back to main memory when we evict a block. Or we just have another management bit (called the dirty bit) which says that our block is the latest and greatest version this implementation would mean we'd have valid, dirty, and tag bits Precondition: $ miss, but no $ line in set 洧녰 is available! We select a line ot replace based on our replacement policy
Random, and more methods implemented. Then based on the address, you have your set index which points to the set of entries. Within that set you iterate over all possible ways and check if the tag matches.
Only check if it is valid
Then we have our block replacement strategies. How do we repalce things on a miss/
If all our cache lines in a set we're coming into are valid, we have to decide what needs to go out. We're going to use the "least recently used" LRU
Then with a write there's a write through and a write back
A through means we update the cache and the main memory. Our cache and main memory are always in sync this way
In a write back: Main memory access is slow anyways, so we're going to write to our cache. Only update back the main memory when we have to evict that cache line. We should subsequently keep track Do we have to worry about the time delay between finishing writing to the cache versus writing to the HDD?
Not in this class, that's only relevant in multiple processes
For replacement bits, we're having it as the log of the number of elements in the row, since we will just keep track of the order it was last accessed. info_displayTitle.description: Descriptive title to show above the feature

info_minCollapseDepth.description: Only allow outline items to be collapsed if they are at least this many levels deep in the tree.

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. (Relative to the selector)

info_displayTitle.description: Descriptive title to show above the feature

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. (Relative to the selector)

info_displayTitle.description: Descriptive title to show above the feature

info_showOrphanNodes.description: Show nodes that are not connected to any other nodes.

info_showAttachments.description: Show attachments like images and PDFs as nodes in the graph.

info_allowGlobalGraph.description: Allow the user to view the global graph of all nodes.

info_allowExpand.description: Allow the user to pop-out the graph view to take up the whole screen

info_attractionForce.description: How much should linked nodes attract each other? This will make the graph appear more clustered.

info_linkLength.description: How long should the links between nodes be? The shorter the links the more connected nodes will cluster together.

info_repulsionForce.description: How much should nodes repel each other? This will make disconnected parts more spread out.

info_centralForce.description: How much should nodes be attracted to the center? This will make the graph appear more dense and circular.

info_edgePruning.description: Edges with a length above this threshold will not be rendered, however they will still contribute to the simulation. This can help large tangled graphs look more organised. Hovering over a node will still display these links.

info_minNodeRadius.description: How small should the smallest nodes be? The smaller a node is the less it will attract other nodes.

info_maxNodeRadius.description: How large should the largest nodes be? Nodes are sized by how many links they have. The larger a node is the more it will attract other nodes. This can be used to create a good grouping around the most important nodes.

info_allowResizing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be resized

info_allowCollapsing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be collapsed

info_rightDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the right sidebar

info_leftDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the left sidebar

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. (Relative to the selector)

info_sourcePath.description: The local path to the source .html file which will be included.

info_allowFoldingLists.description: Whether or not to allow lists to be folded

info_allowFoldingHeadings.description: Whether or not to allow headings to be folded

info_siteUrl.description: The url that this site will be hosted at

info_authorName.description: The name of the author of the site
